abstract.text: To help explain the key concepts of the SDK, we’ll use an example of a fictional hardware retail company called

inlineContent.text: ToolTime

abstract.text: that sells DIY equipment and materials in their three retail spaces found in London, Manchester and Bristol.

inlineContent.text: At the top level is an
organisation
. In most cases you only have one organisation.
In the case of
ToolTime
: this would be an example of an organisation.
A physical store is called a
venue
. It is comprised of different floor levels made up of sections, fixtures and products. Every venue belongs to an organisation.
In the case of
ToolTime
: The retail locations i.e. London, Manchester and Bristol would all be examples of venues.

An API key allows access from a mobile or web application. You generally only create one per platform. These are scoped to an organisation and so API keys give access to all of the organisation’s venues. They can be generated and enabled or disabled within
Do not share the API key publically and take steps to keep it secure since it can be used to access your map data.
In the case of
ToolTime
: ToolTime have an existing iOS retail application called “ToolTime” which they use to offer click-and-collect services with and allow customers to buy products online.
They would like to integrate SpaceKit within their existing app so they generate an API key they embed within the application code.

These maps contain a complete digital twin of a retail environment from walls, sections, floors all the way down to individual fixtures and till points which we render as a 3D map and use to help calculate navigation routes
